channel.title: Comments on: How to clean a table from badly named column names
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: In all seriousness this is useful when you do those create table statement when importing Excel sheets from DTS and SSIS and it has those crazy column names. SO you can use this to quickly 'fix' that table
item.content:encoded: In all seriousness this is useful when you do those create table statement when importing Excel sheets from DTS and SSIS and it has those crazy column names. SO you can use this to quickly ‘fix’ that table

item.title: By: traingamer
item.dc:creator: traingamer
item.description: Very funny - both methods are pretty slick, though.
item.content:encoded: Very funny – both methods are pretty slick, though.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: don't you use SELECT * in your procs?
item.content:encoded: don’t you use SELECT * in your procs?

item.title: By: traingamer
item.dc:creator: traingamer
item.description: Then what do you do to update all of your stored procedures, triggers, etc.?<br /> And what happens when you encounter the genius who has columns in the same table named <em>address1</em> and <em>address_1</em>?
item.content:encoded:
Then what do you do to update all of your stored procedures, triggers, etc.?
And what happens when you encounter the genius who has columns in the same table named address1 and address_1?
